content.text: Node.js Raspberry Pi - Components
What are Components?
Components are parts of a larger whole. In this chapter, we explain the different components we use in our tutorial.
content.html: Components are parts of a larger whole. In this chapter, we explain the different components we use in our tutorial.

content.text: The Raspberry Pi and GPIO Pins
This is an illustration of the Raspberry Pi 3.
content.html: This is an illustration of the Raspberry Pi 3.

content.text: The GPIO pins are the small red squares in two rows on the right side of the Raspberry Pi, on the actual Raspberry Pi they are small metal pins.
content.html: The GPIO pins are the small red squares in two rows on the right side of the Raspberry Pi, on the actual Raspberry Pi they are small metal pins.

content.text: Input pins are like switches that you can turn on or off from the outside world (like a on/off light switch).
content.html: Input pins are like switches that you can turn on or off from the outside world (like a on/off light switch).

content.text: Output pins are like switches that the Raspberry Pi can turn on or off (like turning on/off a LED light).
content.html: Output pins are like switches that the Raspberry Pi can turn on or off (like turning on/off a LED light).

content.text: The Raspberry Pi 3 has 26 GPIO pins, the rest of the pins are power, ground or "other".
content.html: The Raspberry Pi 3 has 26 GPIO pins, the rest of the pins are power, ground or "other".

content.text: The Breadboard

A breadboard is used for prototyping electronics, it allows you to create circuits without soldering. It is basically a plastic board, with a grid of tie-points (holes). Inside the board there are metal strips connecting the different tie-points in specific ways.

content.text: Other Electrical Components
Through Hole LED

Light emitting diode (LED). An LED is a diode that emits light when a voltage is applied to it. In our example we use a Through Hole LED. They have a positive (called Anode), and a negative (called Cathode) pin. The longer leg on the LED should indicate the positive pin.
content.html: Light emitting diode (LED). An LED is a diode that emits light when a voltage is applied to it. In our example we use a Through Hole LED. They have a positive (called Anode), and a negative (called Cathode) pin. The longer leg on the LED should indicate the positive pin.

content.text: RGB LED

Light emitting diode (LED). An LED is a diode that emits light when a voltage is applied to it. An RGB LED has 4 pins. One for each color (R = Red, G = Green, and, B = Blue), and a common cathode/anode. This one LED can display the pure colors, or with PWD to modulate and mix colors.

content.text: Push Button
A push button is a type of switch. A switch makes or breaks a connection an an electric circuit.
content.html: A push button is a type of switch. A switch makes or breaks a connection an an electric circuit.

content.text: Jumper Wire - Female to Male
Short pieces of wire called jumper wires are used to make connections. Female to Male jumper wires can be used to connect from the GPIO on the Raspberry Pi to the Breadboard.
content.html: Short pieces of wire called jumper wires are used to make connections. Female to Male jumper wires can be used to connect from the GPIO on the Raspberry Pi to the Breadboard.

content.text: Jumper Wire - Male to Male
Short pieces of wire called jumper wires are used to make connections. Male to Male jumper wires can be used to make connections between different parts of the Breadboard.
